description: ED note - 65yo M with trach, SOB, multilobar pneumonia
input:
Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
•	Shortness of Breath
 	 65 yo male who is tracheostomy dependent with a PMHx of CAD, DM, GERD, HLD, and HTN presents to ED complaining of shortness of breath. Pt reports he has been having increased secretions over the past week causing him to wake up from his sleep short of breath. He states his secretions have also been thicker causing him to have mucus plug offs for around three days. Pt reports he was treated for pneumonia and finished his last dose of antibiotics yesterday. Pt states today an episode where he woke up short of breath happened, however he does not remember exactly what happened and thinks he may have passed out. Per triage note, nursing home staff called an ambulance for respiratory distress, and was placed on 6 lpm trach collar. Pt reports he uses 2 lpm at home. Pt denies any shortness of breath, fever, and reports no other complaints at this time.
 
Per nursing home - patient finished IV linezolid course several days ago

Review of patient's allergies indicates:
Allergen	Reactions
•	Dextromethorphan	 
 
Past Medical History:
Diagnosis	Date
•	Bacteremia due to Klebsiella pneumoniae	 
•	CAD (coronary artery disease)	 
•	DDD (degenerative disc disease), cervical	 
•	DM (diabetes mellitus), type 2	 
•	Fatty liver	 
•	GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease)	 
•	Gout, unspecified	 
•	HLD (hyperlipidemia)	 
•	HTN (hypertension)	 
•	Hyperthyroidism	 
•	OSA (obstructive sleep apnea)	 
•	SCC (squamous cell carcinoma)	 
 
Review of Systems 
Constitutional:  Negative for chills and fever. 
HENT:  Positive for congestion. Negative for rhinorrhea and sore throat.  
Eyes:  Negative for visual disturbance. 
Respiratory:  Positive for shortness of breath. Negative for cough.  
Cardiovascular:  Negative for chest pain. 
Gastrointestinal:  Negative for abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. 
Genitourinary:  Negative for dysuria and hematuria. 
Musculoskeletal:  Negative for joint swelling. 
Skin:  Negative for rash. 
Neurological:  Positive for syncope. Negative for weakness. 
Psychiatric/Behavioral:  Negative for confusion.  
All other systems reviewed and are negative.

 
Physical Exam
 
Initial Vitals [09/22/25 2310]
BP	Pulse	Resp	Temp	SpO2
(!) 141/76	82	(!) 22	97 °F (36.1 °C)	99 %
 
Physical Exam
 
Nursing note and vitals reviewed.
Constitutional: He is not diaphoretic. No distress. 
HENT: 
Head: Normocephalic and atraumatic. 
Trach tube in place. 
Neck: Neck supple. 
Normal range of motion.
Cardiovascular:  Normal rate and regular rhythm.         
Pulmonary/Chest: Breath sounds normal. No respiratory distress. 
Hypoxic requiring trach collar. Increased secretions requiring frequent suctioning. 
Abdominal: Abdomen is soft. He exhibits no distension. There is no abdominal tenderness. 
Musculoskeletal:    
   General: No edema. 
   Cervical back: Normal range of motion and neck supple. 
 
Neurological: He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. He has normal strength. No cranial nerve deficit or sensory deficit. 
Skin: Skin is warm. Capillary refill takes less than 2 seconds. 
Psychiatric: He has a normal mood and affect. 

 
 
ED Course
Procedures
Labs Reviewed
COMPREHENSIVE METABOLIC PANEL - Abnormal
    Result	Value	
 	Sodium	140 	 
 	Potassium	4.2 	 
 	Chloride	93 (*)	 
 	CO2	38 (*)	 
 	Glucose	128 (*)	 
 	Blood Urea Nitrogen	30.8 (*)	 
 	Creatinine	0.59 (*)	 
 	Calcium	9.6 	 
 	Protein Total	8.9 (*)	 
 	Albumin	3.3 (*)	 
 	Globulin	5.6 (*)	 
 	Albumin/Globulin Ratio	0.6 (*)	 
 	Bilirubin Total	1.1 	 
 	ALP	132 	 
 	ALT	40 	 
 	AST	33 	 
 	eGFR	>60 	 
 	Anion Gap	9.0 	 
 	BUN/Creatinine Ratio	52 	 
NT-PRO NATRIURETIC PEPTIDE - Abnormal
 	NT-proBNP	3,030 (*)	 
CBC WITH DIFFERENTIAL - Abnormal
 	WBC	4.75 	 
 	RBC	3.70 (*)	 
 	Hgb	11.0 (*)	 
 	Hct	37.8 (*)	 
 	MCV	102.2 (*)	 
 	MCH	29.7 	 
 	MCHC	29.1 (*)	 
 	RDW	21.1 (*)	 
 	Platelet	160 	 
 	MPV	9.5 	 
 	Neut %	80.7 	 
 	Lymph %	10.7 	 
 	Mono %	7.4 	 
 	Eos %	0.2 	 
 	Basophil %	0.4 	 
 	Imm Grans %	0.6 	 
 	Neut #	3.83 	 
 	Lymph #	0.51 (*)	 
 	Mono #	0.35 	 
 	Eos #	0.01 	 
 	Baso #	0.02 	 
 	Imm Gran #	0.03 	 
 	NRBC%	0.4 	 
TROPONIN I HIGH SENSITIVITY - Normal
 	Troponin High Sensitive	3 	 
COVID/RSV/FLU A&B PCR - Normal
 	Influenza A PCR	Not Detected 	 
 	Influenza B PCR	Not Detected 	 
 	Respiratory Syncytial Virus PCR	Not Detected 	 
 	SARS-CoV-2 PCR	Not Detected 	 
TROPONIN I HIGH SENSITIVITY - Normal
 	Troponin High Sensitive	4 	 
LACTIC ACID, PLASMA - Normal
 	Lactic Acid Level	1.0 	 
 
EKG Readings: (Independently Interpreted) 
Initial Reading: No STEMI. Rhythm: Normal Sinus Rhythm. Heart Rate: 93. Ectopy: No Ectopy. Conduction: Normal and Bifasicular. ST Segments: Normal ST Segments. T Waves: Normal. Axis: Normal. Clinical Impression: Normal Sinus Rhythm Other Impression: No ischemic changes. 
Taken at 2322.
 
Imaging Results 
 
CT Chest With Contrast (Preliminary result) 	Result time 09/23/25 02:53:18
 
Preliminary result by Schulze, Eric S, MD (09/23/25 02:53:18)
 
Technique: CT Scan of the chest was performed with intravenous contrast with direct axial images as well as sagittal and coronal reconstruction images.
 
Comparison: None.
 
Clinical History: Shortness of Breath (Here via EMS from camelot NH for SOB, pt states that he is unsure what happened and believes he passed out, NH staff called for res distress pt has trach and on 6 liter trach collar, pt awake alert no distress at this time. ).
 
Findings:
Lines and Tubes: A tracheostomy tube is in place.
Mediastinum: A few enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are seen in the lower paratracheal . The largest is in paratracheal space and measures 13.3 mm in least dimension. This suggests lymphadenopathy.
Heart: The heart size is within normal limits. Moderate coronary artery calcification is seen.
Aorta: No aortic dissection or aneurysm is seen. Mild aortic calcification is seen in the thoracic aorta.
Pulmonary Arteries: No filling defects are seen in the pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary embolus.
Lungs: There are scattered patchy ground glass opacities throughout both lungs. . There are small left-greater-than-right bilateral pleural effusions. There are large areas of consolidation including in the bilateral medial lung bases. A small calcified granuloma is seen in the right lower lobe seen on series 2 image 79.
Bony Structures:
Spine: Moderate spondylolytic changes are seen in the thoracic spine.
Ribs: No rib fractures are identified.
Abdomen: Surgical clips are seen in the right upper quadrant suggesting prior cholecystectomy. A gastrostomy tube is seen with its tip in the stomach.
 
 
Impression:
1. A few enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are seen in the lower paratracheal . The largest is in paratracheal space and measures 13.3 mm in least dimension. This suggests lymphadenopathy. Correlate with clinical and laboratory findings as regards further evaluation and follow up.
2. There are scattered patchy ground glass opacities throughout both lungs. . There are small left-greater-than-right bilateral pleural effusions. There are large areas of consolidation including in the bilateral medial lung bases. This is consistent with multilobar pneumonia. Correlate with clinical and laboratory parameters.
3. No filling defects are seen in the pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary embolus.
 
Medications
vancomycin - pharmacy to dose
piperacillin-tazobactam (ZOSYN) 4.5 g in D5W 100 mL IVPB (MB+)
vancomycin (VANCOCIN) 1,000 mg in D5W 250 mL IVPB (admixture device)
piperacillin-tazobactam (ZOSYN) 4.5 g in D5W 100 mL IVPB (MB+)
insulin aspart U-100 injection 0-10 Units
ondansetron injection 4 mg
 
Medical Decision Making
65 yo with SCC, CAD, HTN, HLD presenting with cough, sob, increased trach collar requirements 
Recently finished treatment for pneumonia at nursing home per report
Exam as above
Workup reveals multifocal pneumonia
Will admit for IV abx, respiratory suctioning prn
 
Differential diagnosis (including but not limited to): 
ACS, pneumonia, COVID/Flu, congestive heart failure, asthma, COPD, pleural effusion, pulmonary edema, acute bronchitis, PE, pneumothorax, hemothorax, aortic dissection, electrolyte abnormalities, anemia, anxiety 
 
 
Problems Addressed:
Pneumonia of both lower lobes due to infectious organism: acute illness or injury that poses a threat to life or bodily functions
SOB (shortness of breath): acute illness or injury that poses a threat to life or bodily functions

expected.subjective: 65 yo male who is tracheostomy dependent with a PMHx of CAD, DM, GERD, HLD, and HTN presents to ED complaining of shortness of breath
expected.objective:
BP 141/76, HR 82, RR 22, Temp 97°F, SpO2 99%
No distress, trach tube in place, normal cardiac exam, hypoxic requiring trach collar
expected.assessment: Multilobar pneumonia, bilateral infiltrates on imaging
expected.plan: Admit for IV antibiotics (vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam), respiratory suctioning prn

notes: ED note format - non-standard sections like 'Chief Complaint', 'Review of Systems', 'ED Course'
Labs in tabular format with asterisks for abnormal values
Medications list with detailed IV admixture info
Past medical history as bulleted list
Abbreviations: PMHx, SOB, prn, IV, lpm, NH, EMS
